CURRENTLY_TRACKING: Now tracking your actions in the app
NOT_TRACKING: No longer tracking your actions in the app
DONATE_ALT_TEXT: Link to University of Washington donation website for TCAT.
GITHUB_TEXT: AccessMap is an open source project.
ESCIENCE_ALT_TEXT: Link to University of Washington eScience Institute website.
WSDOT_ALT_TEXT: Link to Washington State Department of Transportation.
UW_TEXT: AccessMap is developed via the Taskar Center at the University of Washington.
ORGANIZATIONS_TEXT: AccessMap has received support from many organizations.
DONATE_TEXT: Contribute to AccessMap development by donating to the Taskar Center. Mention AccessMap in the comment.
TWITTER_TEXT: Follow updates on AccessMap Seattle on Twitter!
EMAIL_TEXT: Email us if you encounter issues or wish to contribute to AccessMap.
CROWDSOURCING_INFO_TEXT: Help AccessMap by reporting issues/features in our dataset. Please note that submitting feedback will not update the map immediately.
utils-send-email-error: Provided URL can not be handled
Header-crowdsourcingInfo-accessibilityLa: Select to report an issue with this segment
FeedbackForm-Index-body: The following issues/features has been reported for
FeedbackForm-Index-swSub3Ft: - Sidewalk below 3 feet at some points
FeedbackForm-Index-TWO_CR: - Both curbramps are present for this crossing
FeedbackForm-Index-cxPedSignal: - This crossing has a pedestrian signal
FeedbackForm-Index-cxAuditorySignal: - This crossing has an auditory signal
FeedbackForm-Index-cxTactileSignal: - This crossing has a tactile signal
SideMenu-about-overlay-Text: Contribute to AccessMap development by donating to the Taskar Center. Mention AccessMap in the comment.
SideMenu-contact-overlay-Text: Email us if you encounter issues or want to help out
MapButtons-zoom-PermissionsAndroid messa: Can AccessMap track your current location?
OmniCard-index-accessibilityLabel: Select to modify custom mobility preferences
OmniCard-mobility-buttons-accessibilityL: * Currently selected / Select to set mode
OmniCard-region-switcher-accessibilityLa: Current Region: *****. Select to change region.
NO_INTERNET: Please check your connection to the internet.
MAP_CAPTION_1: Search bar located at the top of the app. Gray text inside the bar reads: Enter Address
MAP_TUT_1: Set a route start or destination by tapping on the map or entering a location in the Search Bar.
MAP_CAPTION_2: A grey button with an enter symbol to the right of the search bar.
MAP_TUT_2: Alternatively, tap on this grey icon to manually input a start and destination.
MAP_CAPTION_3: Mobility buttons located under the search bar in order: Custom, Wheelchair, Powered, and Cane.
MAP_TUT_3: Customize your travel by selecting the mode of transportation that best fits you. As an example, the Custom Profile is currently selected.
MAP_CAPTION_4: A gray pencil icon button next to the Mobility Mode buttons.
MAP_TUT_4: While in the Custom Profile setting, tap on the pencil icon to adjust route characteristics such as sidewalk steepness.
MAP_CAPTION_5: Three circular buttons on the bottom right of the map. The top one has a target symbol, the middle has a Plus icon, the bottom has a minus icon.
MAP_TUT_5: The three buttons on the right control your view of the map. The top one centers your location, the middle zooms in, and the bottom zooms out.
MAP_CAPTION_6: A rainbow-colored scale representing sidewalk incline levels. Black text below it reads: Speed at incline %.
MAP_TUT_6: This bar shows the mapping of colors to sidewalk steepness levels on the map. Green means a low steepness, while red is very steep. In this example, yellow represents a 2% incline.
MAP_CAPTION_7: Two blue region-switching buttons at the top right corner of the home screen. The left reads: English, the right: Seattle.
MAP_TUT_7: Currently, AccessMap supports showing sidewalk data for Seattle, Mount Vernon, and Bellingham.
ROUTE_CAPTION_1: Home screen with the grey enter button on the top right highlighted. The Map view of Seattle is shown as an example below.
ROUTE_TUT_1: Tap on the map or the grey Enter button to enter a start and destination for your route.
ROUTE_CAPTION_2: Two search bars on top of each other, a cancel button to the right, and a reverse button on the bottom right. The top search bar contents read: Pike Place Market. The bottom one reads: Gum Walls.
ROUTE_TUT_2: In this example, Pike Place Market is set as the route start and Gum Wall is set as the destination.
ROUTE_TUT_3: The top right button cancels selecting a route, and the bottom right button reverses the start and destination.
ROUTE_CAPTION_4: A white card containing route information. The example route is 0.12 miles long and approximately 7 minutes to take. A button on the left reads: Trip info, the right one reads: Directions.
ROUTE_TUT_4: Tap the buttons to reveal trip information and step-by-step directions.
ROUTE_CAPTION_5: A white screen showing route information. An area chart of elevation changes is shown. The x-axis represents distance in feet and the y-axis represents height in feet.
ROUTE_TUT_5: Scroll down to view trip data such as elevation change.
ROUTE_CAPTION_6: A white screen showing a list of directions for an example route. Each step has bold text explaining the action to be done, such as Use the Sidewalk, and the location and distance of the step.
ROUTE_TUT_6: Scroll down to view step-by-step directions for your route.
SETTINGS_CAPTION_1: Static home screen showing map view. The top left hamburger menu button is highlighted.
SETTINGS_TUT_1: Tap on this button to open the settings menu.
SETTINGS_CAPTION_2: The drawer menu is opened from the left side, showing the Tracking Settings switch at the middle bottom. It is untoggled.
SETTINGS_TUT_2: Toggling this will allow the app to track the actions you take in this app. Your information is kept completely confidential.
SETTINGS_CAPTION_3: Below the Tracking Settings switch is the Showing Imperial Units switch. It is untoggled.
SETTINGS_TUT_3: Toggling this will change the units displayed in the app.
USER_TRACKING_TEXT: Turning on 'track user data' will allow us to collect data on user actions, such as the frequency of buttons pressed on the map. This allows us to better understand how users interact with AccessMap. No personal or identifying information will be stored or linked to your actions. By clicking OK, you consent to this data collection.
